title: High School Crystal Growth Challenge 2024
preview: The annual challenge brought together 50 students to learn about supersaturation, nucleation, and crystal habit in our labs.
body:
# Event Success: High School Crystal Growth Challenge

The Welch Center hosted its annual High School Crystal Growth Challenge, bringing together 50 talented students from various Houston-area high schools.

## The Experience

Participants spent a full day in our advanced microscopy and wet labs. The focus was on applied physical chemistry, teaching students the principles of **controlled crystallization** that underpin pharmaceutical development.

### Key Takeaways:

* **Nucleation:** Understanding the critical size required for a crystal seed to survive.
* **Growth:** The influence of temperature and agitation on growth kinetics.
* **Purity:** Techniques for minimizing impurities to achieve perfect crystal habit.

The winning team, 'Crystal Clear Minds,' grew the largest and most perfect potassium alum crystal, earning them scholarships to the UH summer science program. "It was amazing to see science in action," said team leader Maria Rodriguez.

This initiative helps demystify advanced materials science and provides hands-on experience not typically available in high school settings. We look forward to next year's competition!

title: Mentoring Future Scientists at Houston Science Fair
preview: Welch Center faculty and graduate students volunteered as mentors and judges at the Greater Houston Area Science Fair, guiding young innovators.
body:
# Supporting Local STEM: Mentorship Program

For the third consecutive year, Welch Center faculty and graduate students volunteered as mentors and judges at the Greater Houston Area Science Fair. Our involvement aims to provide meaningful feedback beyond just grading.

## Faculty Engagement

Our team provided specialized guidance to dozens of middle and high school students on advanced projects related to chemical synthesis, environmental science, and computational modeling.

*Dr. Peter Rimer emphasized the importance of clear communication and experimental design.*

"Engaging with these bright students is incredibly rewarding," he noted. "They are the future innovators who will tackle energy and pharmaceutical challenges."

We are proud to support local education and inspire careers in materials engineering and chemistry.

title: University Day: Inside the Crystallization Lab
preview: Prospective UH students and their families toured our labs and witnessed live crystal growth demonstrations.
body:
# An Inside Look: University Day Open House

During University Day 2024, the Welch Center opened its doors to prospective UH students and their families.

## What Visitors Saw

Over 100 visitors toured our advanced microscopy and spectroscopy labs. Highlights included:

1.  **Live TEM Feed:** Real-time observation of nanopartice self-assembly.
2.  **Crystal Growth Station:** Demonstrations on how to grow perfect, large single crystals.
3.  **Molecular Simulation Demos:** Interactive stations showing Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations in action.

PhD candidate Emily Chen led a popular station demonstrating how temperature affects solubility, explaining the basis of phase diagrams. The tours provided a unique glimpse into the cutting-edge research environment at the University of Houston.
